I'll ask the questions.
So can you please just tell us your name and where and when you were born?
My name is Jabeen. I'm born in Kampala, Uganda. That's in East Africa.
I came here in 1972 as a refugee.
Are you okay to say that in Swahili?
Yes. Swahili I can't remember all of it. I'll speak in our own language.
My name is Jabeen. I'm born in Uganda, East Africa.
I've been a refugee for 50 years.
When did you say you were born as well?
I was born on the 15th of September 1958.
First section we're just going to talk about growing up outside of the UK.
What do you remember about the area that you grew up in?
When I was in Uganda, we came here in 1972. I used to be about 8 years old.
We used to go to school there. The schooling was different from here because we were more in primary schools.
So when we came here they put us in secondary school so that was a very big step.
Mostly we just went to school there and we had to pay fees.
We used to celebrate independence there, all the events because all the different people,
Muslims, Hindus, Christians, we all used to go to the same school.
So if it's Christmas we go to the church and then when it's Diwali we go to the Hindu temple.
But Muslims we used to go to the mosque and then we had all African children as well with us.
So all nationalities were together and we all grew up together.
The English was the main language there and then you could speak Swahili.
That's the Ugandan and there's a Ugandan language as well.
There were many different languages but the main was English.
So when I came here it was a bit easier for us.
Because you learnt how to speak English.
Yes, English was probably there.
So what was it like growing up in the house?
We were like a big family living in a small house and we had grandparents and all that.
So we used to go and visit them.
Then we used to, like weekends we used to go to the lake side, have a picnic.
It was nice to go to the neighbour's house, mingle with them, with their festival and all that.
So it was completely different when we came here.
We used to go to the markets, local markets.
What did you kind of love the most or enjoy the most about Krona?
Growing up there the weather was nice.
We very hardly had the rain.
In East Africa the weather was always nice.
A lot of greenery.
We used to go for long walks in the riverside.
It was so safe, you know.
You didn't hear anything.
In the end somebody kidnapped you or abused you or nothing like that.
Everything was safe.
You could walk miles and miles in the jungle and nobody bothered you.
The people were very friendly.
What did you think about your childhood?
I didn't have much childhood because we went that well off.
We were just taking easy days to come.
So it was just a simple life, but no stress.
We just wake up in the morning, go to school half day, come home, eat and just play outside.
No computers, no television, nothing like that.
Just people mingling together.
What type of games did you play?
We used to play hip hop.
We used to have chalk and just play on the ground.
And just climb trees picking mangoes.
And just had a few toys, not much toys like we do here.
Just had a few old fashioned toys.
We had our grandparents get them for us.
My mum used to cook. We didn't have cookers or anything.
We used to just help around.
If you do the house chores, my mum used to give us money to buy sweets.
So everything we had to earn.
And hip hop, was that with the squares?
Yes, squares.
And then you would throw?
Yes, throw.
And then skipping rope we used to use and skip.
That was just our way of, you know, because the weather was always dry.
And we just looked forward to that.
All the children get together from the neighbourhoods.
And we just played that.
So then travelling, I was just making sure hip hop because it was the same.
Growing up in Zimbabwe, so I was exactly the same.
I was trying to remember whether we did throw the stone and then we would go.
And have hope.
So travelling to the UK, what made you decide to come to the UK?
In 1972, the president of Uganda gave all white people, Jews, Asians, all mixed race people,
to leave the country within 90 days.
So all we were allowed to do is, if you have a British passport, you can come to Britain.
So in 1947, 1960, the British used to rule everything.
And then they decided, who wants to become British citizens?
Or you can have African status.
So my mum decided to be British, take British passport.
And my dad was Ugandan.
So then he had a problem coming.
So anybody with a British passport, you have to leave.
They came and started breaking the house and kidnapping people.
Very, very rough, like a ritual regime.
And then we were all six brothers and sisters.
So all of us came with my mum.
So we had to catch a flight from there.
We didn't have ticket money or anything.
So then we had to go to the church, temples, Guru Dwaray, and get money for the tickets to come here.
All we were allowed was 20 shillings, that's about two pounds.
And one suitcase each.
And we were little, so we didn't know what was happening.
So we went to the airport and waited for the flight and they brought us to Heathrow.
Because we were little, we didn't understand much.
But I remember what used to happen there, you know.
It was getting really bad.
And then from the airport, they brought us to Heathrow.
So in Heathrow, we had the National Front and them.
They said they were not coming here, there were 90,000 Asians.
Because all the Jews went to Israel and all different nationalities.
So you had a choice.

they send you to Mexico, Peru, or Britain had to take us.
Because my mum had a passport and we were all underage.
When we came here, it was difficult.

Big camp.
